command line options

 DAQlml : DAQlml v0.4.4: DAta AcQuisition program of LML (Oct 31 2012, 16:38:20)

    -v               0                        verbose option
    --info           0                        information
    --help           0                        help (or -h option)
    --fd             /dev/comedi0             board device file
    --fp             parameters.nc            input parameter file
    --fo             data.nc                  output data file
    -t               true                     create time axis
    -c               true                     convert 16bit int value into voltage
    --test           0                        test, 0: no test, 1: square wave test
    --boardinfo      0                        print board info
    --show           0                        display result as a graph, 0: no display 1: data (and histogram on test) 2: + errors 3: + raw data/clean data
    --buffer         false                    acquisition type

CDL parameter file

Use NetCDF library tool ncgen to compile parameters.cdl text file to parameters.nc binary file (e.g. ncgen parameters.cdl -o parameters.nc). 

netcdf DAQlml.parameters {//written in NetCDF CDL language
//dimensions:

//variable declaration and attributes
variables:
//acquisition
  int acquisition;
    acquisition:range_id = 0;//[-10..+10] Volts
    acquisition:channels = 0,1,2;
    acquisition:sampling_rate =      100000; //not used in point to point acquisition
    acquisition:number_of_samples =  10000;
    acquisition:channel_name= "chan0, chan1, chan2";
//control
  int control;
data:
  acquisition=1;
  control=0;
}

documentation outline

This is the reference documentation of DAQlml, from the LML.

DAQlml is a data acquisition software. The program begins in the main function in the main.cpp source file.

This documentation has been automatically generated from the DAQlml sources, using the tool doxygen. It should be readed as HTML, LaTex and man page.
It contains both

  • a detailed description of all classes and functions
  • a user guide (cf. related pages)

that as been documented in the sources.

Additional needed libraries:
  • the CImg Library using ImageMagick for a few image format
  • NetCDF (network Common Data Form)
Optional libraries:
  • FFTw (Fastest Fourier Transform in the West) though CImg library
  • added to CImg raw, Hiris, PCO and LaVision images support
  • libPNG (Portable Network Graphics) using zLib (non destructive compression)
  • libTIFF (Tag Image File Format)
  • parallelism MPI (Message Passing Interface)
  • data format ParaView
  • vector graphics Board (A vector graphics C++ library: Postscript, SVG and Fig files)
  • parallelism pThread (POSIX thread)
  • Boost.org (aims to C++ Standard Library) libs
  • Blitz++ (C++ class library for scientific computing)
  • TNT (Template Numerical Toolkit = PACK of Lapack++, Sparselib++, IML++, and MV++) , ...

make documentation using Doxygen syntax

Each function in the source code should be commented using doxygen syntax in the same file. The documentation need to be written before the function. The basic syntax is presented in this part. 

//!This comment will be both in declaration and explanation of the function
/**
 * This comment will be in explanation part only
**/

Two kind of comments are needed for declaration and explanation parts of the function: Standart documentation should the following (sample of code documentation): 

//!BothInDeclarationNExplanation
/** 
 * InExplanationPartOnly
 * \param arg1 = ExplanationOnThisFunctionArgument
 * \param arg2 = ExplanationOnThisFunctionArgument
 *
 * \code
 *   AnExampleOfUse
 * \endcode
 *
 * \see AnOtherFunctionOrAvariable
**/

In both declaration and explanation part, writting and highlithing syntax can be the following:

  • \n a new line
  • \li a list (dot list)
  • \b bold style
  • \c code style
  • \e enhanced style (italic)

For making shortcut please use:

  • \see to make a shortcut to a related function or variable
  • \link to make a shortcut to a file or a function
    Note:
    this keyword needs to be closed using \end*
    While coding or debugging, please use intensively:
  • \todo to add a thing to do in the list of ToDo for the whole program
  • \bug to add an a priori or known bug in the list of Bug for the whole program

In explanation part, paragraph style can be the following:

  • \code for an example of the function use
  • \note to add a few notes
  • \attention for SOMETHING NOT FULLY DEFINED YET
  • \warning to give a few warning on the function
    Note:
    these keywords need to be closed using \end* 
    \code
  WriteYourExample
\endcode

Many other keywords are defined, so please read the documentation of doxygen.
